Thank you  Jrebak and Philip,
                                                   I was trying figure out
what exactly is the reason for the issue I am facing. Below is the few
things I noticed.  I paste below the last portion of the times series I
have been working on.
I have a time series which is 10 minutes per day and then on last day the
day is not complete in which case I get a wrong answer for any re-sample
function.

I guess this is because the code do not look for what is available to it
for a day and calculates.  or other wards, if I input a time series which
is part of a day towards its end then there is an issue. I hope this can be
sorted out .

Freq: D

This apparently is is wrong.

it should have been .75

0.75 is the **population** standard deviation. pandas calculates the **sample** standard deviation. in short, the reason to use this is because the population stdev is _not_ an [unbiased estimator](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias_of_an_estimator) of the population stdev. most people usually don't care about the population stdev because they are trying to estimate it or they are using a test statistic or using a model that needs an estimate of it. i'm not sure how to get around this since there seems to be an issue with passing a function to resample...

@jreback is this a bug?

```
In [64]: s = Series([30.1, 31.6], date_range('1/1/2000', periods=2, freq='10T'))

In [65]: s
Out[65]:
2000-01-01 00:00:00    30.1
2000-01-01 00:10:00    31.6
Freq: 10T, dtype: float64

In [66]: s.resample('D', how=lambda x: mean(x))
Out[66]:
2000-01-01   NaN
Freq: D, dtype: float64
```

i think, for example, this `lambda x: mean(x) == mean == 'mean'` should be `True` for the `how` parameter, and any general `'f'` too, probably. (Yes that syntax is ambiguous)

I think its an inconsistency  

```
In [6]: s.resample('D', how=lambda x: np.mean(x),closed='right')
Out[6]: 
1999-12-31    30.1
2000-01-01    31.6
Freq: D, dtype: float64
```

```
In [9]: s.resample('D').mean()
Out[9]: 30.850000000000001

```

So  is it possible to fix this or it soon or it is a major revision?
with best regards,
Sudheer

@jsudheer i'm a little confused about what your issue is, it sounds like you weren't aware of the fact that pandas is computing the sample standard deviation, so that is not a bug. i will open up a new issue for the inconsistency shown above. can we close _this_ issue? the [documentation on descriptive statistics](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/dev/basics.html#descriptive-statistics) could maybe be more explicit about this (unless it's mentioned elsewhere in the docs), but there's no bug here.

@Philip,
               I thought if the user is given the choice of either
sample/population sd  by way of adding a switch 1 for sample and 2 for
population then that will be ideal. or making 2 separately like psd and
ssd  for population and sample standard deviation. or I think I should
multiply  the output by (n-1) and then divide by n which will give the
population sd for me.

with best regards,
Sudheer

@jsudheer make sure you're referring to the correct person on github, Philip is someone else. @cpcloud is my handle, so use that since you don't want to start tagging people who have nothing to do with pandas and spam their inbox so to speak. the reason i'm going to raise the issue above is so that you can pass in a modified version of `std` using `partial` or something like that, which will be slow for now, but maybe we can also raise an issue to allow speedy population std deviation computation. you would have to _square_ your output, multply by n - 1, divide by n, _then_ take the square root, since the normalization happens under the square root...

Thank you,
I saw your name as Philip appearing in gmail sorry about that.
With best regards,
Sudheer

## 

Sent from my iPad Mini

Hi,
               Is there a way to get the number of good data used for
calculation of the statistics using pandas.?. For example I have a time
series data which may  have a masked part in it or data having some other
issue. In any case is there a way to get how many actual data points are
being used for calculation of a statistical parameter in pandas. In present
case I wanted write a piece of code to get the population standard
deviation from the sample standard deviation.

to do that
I can write
ssd=ts[53153:53155].resample('D',how='std')
psd=np.sqrt((np.square(ssd)*(len(ts)-1) )/len(ts))
but the issue is that if there are masked elements in ts then I will be
wrong.

I am not sure if this is the correct forum to post this but thought as it
is about pandas, I should ask here. Please excuse me and correct me if
there is another place to post such questions.

wit best regards,
Sudheer

http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/dev/groupby.html#applying-different-functions-to-dataframe-columns

resample is just a special case of groupby, so how can be a custom function that you define (or a lambda)
taking a single argument. You return a value based on that passed series (which is a group). You can do any calculation you want in that function.

Thank you,

Sorry about troubling you

you can always do:

ts.resample('D',how=how)

def how(s):
return whatever you want to compute

``

## 

Sent from my iPad Mini

`how` can be a function

e.g.

```
def how(s):
    return s.std()
```

`ts.resample('D',how='std')`
is the same as
`ts.resample('D',how=how)`

but you can compute and return what you need in `how` exactly how you need to compute it; it gets passed the grouped series. you can then compute std exactly like you want

Thank you,
                            I am trying to understand how really it works!
with best regards,
Sudheer
